case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. the respondents

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 326 of 1957 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 326 of 1957.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 16, 1955, of the Orissa High Court in N. J. C. No. 117 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 16, 1955, of the Orissa High Court in N. J. C. No. 117 of 1951.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by KAPUR, J. on May 5, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. May 5. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-This appeal pursuant to special leave is brought by the Commissioner

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax appealed against Orissa High Court judgment holding amounts received by assessees not received in British India and not liable to income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: of lncome-tax against the judgment of the High Court of Orissa holding that the amounts received by the assessees-respondents were number received in what was British India and therefore number liable to income-tax.

facts.text: Respondents were non-residents carrying on business at Secunderabad in territories of Nizam of Hyderabad.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents at all material times were number-residents carrying on business at Secunderabad which was then in the territories of the Nizam of Hyderabad.

facts.text: Respondents acted as agents for supply of gas plants manufactured by T. V. S. Iyengar Sons, Madura, to Nizams Government.

anchor.surface_text: They acted as agents for the supply of gas plants manufactured by Messrs. T. V. S. Iyengar Sons, Madura, to the Nizams Government, and also as agents of the Lucas Indian Services, Bombay branch,

facts.text: Respondents acted as agents of Lucas Indian Services, Bombay branch, for supply of certain goods to Nizams Government.

anchor.surface_text: and also as agents of the Lucas Indian Services, Bombay branch, for the supply of certain goods to that Government. The year of assessment is 1945-46.

facts.text: Year of assessment is 1945-46.

anchor.surface_text: The year of assessment is 1945-46.

facts.text: No written agreement between manufacturers and respondents; goods supplied on commission basis.

anchor.surface_text: There does number appear to have been any written agreement between the two manufacturers and the respondents but the goods were to be supplied on a companymission basis.

facts.text: Respondents received Rs. 35,202 from T.V.S. Iyengar Sons, Madura, by cheques on Imperial Bank of India, Madras.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of this agreement the respondents received from M s. T.V.S. lyengar Sons, Madura, cheques drawn on the Imperial Bank of India, Madras, amounting to Rs. 35,202 in respect of all goods supplied from -Madura

facts.text: Respondents received Rs. 5,302 from Lucas Indian Services, Bombay, by cheques on Imperial Bank of India, Bombay branch.

anchor.surface_text: and also from Lucas Indian Services, Bombay, by cheques drawn on Imperial Bank of India, Bombay branch, amounting to Rs. 5,302 in respect of goods supplied by them, thus making a total of Rs. 40,504.

facts.text: Total commission received: Rs. 40,504.

anchor.surface_text: thus making a total of Rs. 40,504.

facts.text: Cheques were sent by post and received by respondents at Secunderabad.

anchor.surface_text: These cheques were sent by post and when received by the respondents at Secunderabad were credited in the account books of the respondents and sent to their banker G. Raghunathmal

facts.text: Cheques credited in respondents' account books and sent to banker G. Raghunathmal for collection and crediting.

anchor.surface_text: were credited in the account books of the respondents and sent to their banker G. Raghunathmal for companylecting and crediting to the account of the respondents.

facts.text: Respondents drew cheques immediately against the deposited sums.

anchor.surface_text: As against these sums so deposited the respondents at once drew cheques and thus operated on these amounts deposited.

facts.text: Commission from Bombay firm paid into account on December 22, 1944, credited on January 2, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the companymission received from the Bombay firm it was paid into the account on December 22, 1944, but was given credit for only on January 2, 1945.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer assessed Rs. 40,504 as taxable income received in British India.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer assessed these sums as taxable income holding that the entire amount of Rs. 40,504 was received in British India and number at Secunderabad.

facts.text: Appeal to Appellate Assistant Commissioner who upheld ITO order.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal was taken by the respondents to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner who upheld the order holding that income must be held to have accrued, arisen or received in British India.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held amounts received at Secunderabad and allowed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order the respondents took an appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal and it was held that the amounts were received by the respondents from Madura and Bombay firms as companymission but they were received at Secunderabad.

facts.text: Reference under s. 66(1) to Orissa High Court on whether sums were income received in British India.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the Commissioner a reference under s. 66 1  of the Act was made to the High Court of Orissa for their opinion on the following question - Whether in the circumstances of the case, the sums of Rs. 35,202 and Rs. 5,302

facts.text: High Court found statement of case imperfect and remitted to Tribunal for supplementary statement.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court found that the statement of case was imperfect and that the real question was different. ... It therefore remitted the case to the Appellate Tribunal for submission of supplementary statement of case.

facts.text: Tribunal in supplementary statement found cheques received in full satisfaction of commission.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal in its supplementary statement found that the companyrse of companyduct followed by the parties showed that the cheques were received from the Bombay and Madura firms in full satisfaction of the companymission ascertained from time to time

facts.text: High Court decided against Revenue, answered question against Revenue.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was decided by the High Court against the appellant and in the meanwhile this Court had given a judgment in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Ogale Glass Works Ltd  1 .

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court refused to give leave to appeal to this Court and it was this Court which gave special leave to appeal.

facts.text: All cheques sent from Madura or Bombay and received by respondents at Secunderabad and treated as payment.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal found that all the cheques whether from Madura or from Bombay were sent by the two respective firms from Madura or Bombay and were received by the respondents at Secunderabad and were treated as payment.

facts.text: Verbally agreed that commission would be paid at Secunderabad in cash or by cheque.

anchor.surface_text: There is in support of the respondents an affidavit which was filed in the assessment proceedings and which was relied upon in the High Court. According to this affidavit it was verbally agreed that the companymission would be paid at Secunderabad in cash or by cheque  as the case may be ,

facts.text: Cheques from Bombay and Madura posted from those places.

anchor.surface_text: The question still remains as to the effect of the sending of the cheques from Madura or Bombay by post.

facts.text: Entries made in assessees books, cheques put into bank immediately, bank gave credit after discount, allowed operation.

anchor.surface_text: The facts that such entries were made in the assessees books, that the cheques were put into the bank immediately, that the bank at once gave credit to the assessee for these sums after charging discount thereon and immediately allowed the assessee to operate on those sums are significant .

This appeal pursuant to special leave is brought by the Commissioner of lncome-tax against the judgment of the High Court of Orissa holding that the amounts received by the assessees-respondents were number received in what was British India and therefore number liable to income-tax.
The High Court refused to give leave to appeal to this Court and it was this Court which gave special leave to appeal.

issues.text: Whether in the circumstances of the case, the sums of Rs. 35,202 and Rs. 5,302 received as commission from T. V. S. lyengar Sons Ltd., and Lucas Indian Services Ltd., respectively were income that accrued, arose or were received in British India

anchor.surface_text: Whether in the circumstances of the case, the sums of Rs. 35,202 and Rs. 5,302 received as companymission from T. V. S. lyengar Sons Ltd., and Lucas Indian Services Ltd., respectively were income that accrued, arose or were received in British India .

issues.text: The real question is whether when the cheques were received by the assessee having his place of business outside British India, those cheques were in fact received as absolute and final payments by way of unconditional discharge or whether they were received as mere conditional payments on realisation

anchor.surface_text: The High Court found that the statement of case was imperfect and that the real question was different. It said The real question in all such cases is number merely whether the cheques were drawn on a bank in British India, and sent for companylection to that bank. The question is whether when the cheques were received by the assessee having his place of business outside British India, those cheques were in fact received as absolute and final payments by way of unconditional discharge or whether they were received as mere companyditional payments on realisation.

issues.text: The question is whether the amounts, of commission paid by cheques, drawn respectively on banks at Madras and Bombay and respectively posted from Madura and Bombay, can in the circumstances of this case be held to have been received in what was British India or at Secunderabad

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether the amounts, of companymission paid by cheques, drawn respectively on banks at Madras and Bombay and respectively posted from Madura and Bombay, can in the circumstances of this case be held to have been received in what was British India or at Secunderabad ?

issues.text: Whether the post office is an agent of the creditor if there is express or implied authority to send the cheque by post

anchor.surface_text: In the case of payment by cheques sent by post the determination of the place of payment would depend upon the agreement between the parties or the course of conduct of the parties. If it is shown that the creditor authorised the debtor either expressly or impliedly to send a cheque by post the property in the cheque passes to the creditor as soon as it is posted.

issues.text: Whether according to the course of business usage the parties must have intended that the cheques should be sent by post

anchor.surface_text: according to the course of business usage in general which has to be considered as a part of the surrounding circumstances the parties must have intended that the cheques should be sent by post which is the usual and normal mode of transmission

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer assessed these sums as taxable income holding that the entire amount of Rs. 40,504 was received in British India and not at Secunderabad.

arguments.claim: income must be held to have accrued, arisen or received in British India

arguments.claim: the amounts were received at Secunderabad; cheques being negotiable instruments accepted equivalent to cash payment there

anchor.surface_text: The finding Of the Appellate Tribunal in their own words was- The contention of the Appellants is that the cheques being negotiable instruments and the creditor having accepted them and passed through their books, the receipt must be taken to be receipts in Hyderabad. We agree with the view submitted by the appellants. In Bhashyams Negotiable Instruments Act, 8th Edition, Revised, page 556, it is stated that it will be open to a creditor to accept a cheque in absolute payment of money due to him, in which case it will be equivalent to cash payment. That being the position it cannot be said that the income was received in British India .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: n British India would amount to a final discharge or an unconditional one. The Tribunal in its supplementary statement found that the companyrse of co

arguments.claim: the real question is whether cheques were received as absolute and final payments or mere conditional payments on realisation

anchor.surface_text: The High Court found that the statement of case was imperfect and that the real question was different. It said The real question in all such cases is not merely whether the cheques were drawn on a bank in British India, and sent for collection to that bank. The question is whether when the cheques were received by the assessee having his place of business outside British India, those cheques were in fact received as absolute and final payments by way of unconditional discharge or whether they were received as mere conditional payments on realisation.

arguments.claim: place of payment by cheque sent by post depends on agreement or course of conduct; creditor authorisation (express or implied) makes post office its agent, payment on posting

anchor.surface_text: In the case of payment by cheques sent by post the determination of the place of payment would depend upon the agreement between the parties or the course of conduct of the parties. If it is shown that the creditor authorised the debtor either expressly or impliedly to send a cheque by post the property in the cheque passes to the creditor as soon as it is posted. Therefore the post office is an agent of the person to whom the cheque is posted if there be an express or implied authority to send it by post Commissioner of Income-tax v. Ogale Glass Works Ltd.

arguments.claim: in absence of request express or implied, post office is agent of sender

anchor.surface_text: But it was argued for the respondents that in the absence of such a request the post office could not be constituted as the agent of the creditor and relied on a passage in Ogales case 1 at p. 204 where it was observed- Of course if there be no such request, express or implied, then the delivery of the letter or the cheque to the post office is delivery to the agent of the sender himself .

arguments.claim: course of business usage implies parties intended cheques sent by post, usual mode; post office agent of creditor

anchor.surface_text: according to the course of business usage in general which has to be considered as a part of the surrounding circumstances the parties must have intended that the cheques should be sent by post which is the usual and normal mode of transmission and therefore the posting of cheques in Delhi amounted to payment in Delhi to the post office which was constituted the agent of the assessee.

arguments.claim: express agreement payment at Secunderabad means matter does not fall within Ogale Glass Works rule

anchor.surface_text: It was further contended that in this case there was an express agreement that the payment was to be made at Secunderabad and therefore the matter does not fall within the rule in Ogale Glass Works case 1 and the following principle laid down in judgment by Das, J. as he then was , is inapplicable -

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ough number specific was that the receipt of the cheque by the respondents operated as full discharge of the debt due on account of companymission fro

holdings.text: In the case of payment by cheques sent by post the determination of the place of payment would depend upon the agreement between the parties or the course of conduct of the parties. If it is shown that the creditor authorised the debtor either expressly or impliedly to send a cheque by post the property in the cheque passes to the creditor as soon as it is posted. Therefore the post office is an agent of the person to whom the cheque is posted if there be an express or implied authority to send it by post.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of payment by cheques sent by post the determination of the place of payment would depend upon the agreement between the parties or the course of conduct of the parties. If it is shown that the creditor authorised the debtor either expressly or impliedly to send a cheque by post the property in the cheque passes to the creditor as soon as it is posted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restates binding principle from Commissioner of Income-tax v. Ogale Glass Works Ltd., applying agency rules to determine place of receipt based on express or implied creditor authorization for postal transmission.

holdings.text: according to the course of business usage in general which has to be considered as a part of the surrounding circumstances the parties must have intended that the cheques should be sent by post which is the usual and normal mode of transmission and therefore the posting of cheques in Delhi amounted to payment in Delhi to the post office which was constituted the agent of the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: according to the course of business usage in general which has to be considered as a part of the surrounding circumstances the parties must have intended that the cheques should be sent by post which is the usual and normal mode of transmission and therefore the posting of cheques in Delhi amounted to payment in Delhi to the post office which was constituted the agent of the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Ogale Glass Works Ltd. by finding implied authorization from general course of business usage as surrounding circumstance, making post office agent of creditor upon posting.

holdings.text: the sums of Rs. 35,202 and Rs. 5,302 received as commission from T. V. S. lyengar Sons Ltd., and Lucas Indian Services Ltd., respectively were income that accrued, arose or were received in British India

anchor.surface_text: Whether in the circumstances of the case, the sums of Rs. 35,202 and Rs. 5,302 received as commission from T. V. S. lyengar Sons Ltd., and Lucas Indian Services Ltd., respectively were income that accrued, arose or were received in British India .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies statutory test under Income-tax Act s.4(1) via agency doctrine and Ogale precedent to facts of cheques posted from British India, holding receipt complete on posting.

holdings.text: the amounts, of commission paid by cheques, drawn respectively on banks at Madras and Bombay and respectively posted from Madura and Bombay, can in the circumstances of this case be held to have been received in what was British India

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether the amounts, of commission paid by cheques, drawn respectively on banks at Madras and Bombay and respectively posted from Madura and Bombay, can in the circumstances of this case be held to have been received in what was British India or at Secunderabad ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show cheques posted from British India locations with implied authorization via business course, constituting receipt there per agency principles.

holdings.text: the cheques were received from the Bombay and Madura firms in full satisfaction of the commission ascertained from time to time and due on such date

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal in its supplementary statement found that the course of conduct followed by the parties showed that the cheques were received from the Bombay and Madura firms in full satisfaction of the commission ascertained from time to time

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts Tribunal's factual finding on absolute discharge based on conduct like book entries and immediate banking, but place determined separately.

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Ogale Glass Works Ltd  1 . Even after companysidering the decision of that case the High Court was of the opinion that the income of the respondents was number received in British India and answered the question against the Revenue. The High Court refused to give leave to appeal to this Court and it was this Court which gave special leave to appeal.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Ogale Glass Works Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: judgment on whether income received by cheques posted from British India was received in British India

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Ogale Glass Works Ltd.  1

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Ogale Glass Works Ltd.  1  . In that case there was an express request of the assessee to remit the amount of the bills outstanding against the debtor, that is, Government of India by means of cheques. But it was observed by this Court that according to the companyrse of business usage in general which has to be companysidered as a part of the surrounding circumstances the parties must have intended that the cheques should be sent by post which is the usual and numbermal mode of transmission and therefore the posting of cheques in Delhi amounted to payment in  1  1955 1 S.C.R. 185.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Ogale Glass Works Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: the post office is an agent of the person to whom the cheque is posted if there be an express or implied authority to send it by post

anchor.surface_text: Ogales case  1  at p. 204 where it was observed- Of companyrse if there be numbersuch request, express or implied, then the delivery of the letter or the cheque to the post office is delivery to the agent of the sender himself . It was further companytended that in this case there was an express agreement that the payment was to be made at Secunderabad and therefore the matter does number fall within the rule in Ogale Glass Works case  1  and the following principle laid down in judgment by Das, J.

precedents.cited_proposition: if there be no such request, express or implied, then the delivery of the letter or the cheque to the post office is delivery to the agent of the sender himself
precedents.cited_holding: Of companyrse if there be numbersuch request, express or implied, then the delivery of the letter or the cheque to the post office is delivery to the agent of the sender himself

anchor.surface_text: Ogale Glass Works case  1  and the following principle laid down in judgment by Das, J.  as he then was , is inapplicable - Applying the above principles to the facts found by the Tribunal the position appears to be this. The engagement of the Government was to make payment by cheques. The cheques were drawn in Delhi and received by the assessee in Aundh by post. According to the companyrse of business usage to which, as part of the surrounding circumstances, attention has to be paid under the authorities cited above, the parties must have intended that the cheques should be sent by post which is the usual and numbermal agency for transmission of such articles and according to the Tribunals finding they were in fact received by the assessee by post.

precedents.cited_proposition: according to the course of business usage... the parties must have intended that the cheques should be sent by post which is the usual and normal agency for transmission
precedents.cited_holding: Applying the above principles to the facts found by the Tribunal the position appears to be this. The engagement of the Government was to make payment by cheques. The cheques were drawn in Delhi and received by the assessee in Aundh by post. According to the course of business usage to which, as part of the surrounding circumstances, attention has to be paid under the authorities cited above, the parties must have intended that the cheques should be sent by post which is the usual and normal agency for transmission of such articles and according to the Tribunals finding they were in fact received by the assessee by post.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of payment by cheques sent by post the determination of the place of payment would depend upon the agreement between the parties or the course of conduct of the parties. If it is shown that the creditor authorised the debtor either expressly or impliedly to send a cheque by post the property in the cheque passes to the creditor as soon as it is posted.
here be numbersuch request, express or implied, then the delivery of the letter or the cheque to the post office is delivery to the agent of the sende

edges.explanation: Holding concludes parties must have intended cheques sent by post according to course of business usage, addressing the issue.

anchor.surface_text: according to the course of business usage in general which has to be considered as a part of the surrounding circumstances the parties must have intended that the cheques should be sent by post which is the usual and normal mode of transmission and therefore the posting of cheques in Delhi amounted to payment in Delhi to the post office which was constituted the agent of the assessee.
